Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real functions satisfying the system of differential equations \\( \\dot{x} = Ax + By \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = Cx + Dy \\). An integral transform \\( T(z) = \\int e^{st}z(t) dt \\) is applied where s is a complex number.

If we apply the transform \\( T(z) \\) to the function \\( z(t) \\) and then let the system evolve according to the given differential equations, will \\( T(z) \\) at time t = T still provide the same transformational output as if \\( z(t) \\) evolved directly without the application of \\( T(z) \\)?
Explanation: The transform \\( T(z) \\) fundamentally captures an integral representation over time, changing the perspective of how the state evolves. The subsequent behavior under the differential equations is not incorporated in the transform taken at an initial time, hence the output will be different.
